intro: Phacelia imbricata var. bernardina, commonly known as Bernard's phacelia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and clusters of small, blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and thrives in full sun. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a fuzzy texture, contributing to its distinctive appearance. It is valued for its ornamental appeal and role in supporting local pollinators.
